resources.string: Wires attached to your baby\'s chest are hooked up to a screen that monitors your baby\'s heart rate, breathing rate, and oxygen in their blood.
A type of IV that is in your baby\'s chest to give your baby fluids, nutrients, or medications.
A device that is put over your baby\'s nose to help them breathe. It is also called "CPAP".
A type of bed that is closed on all sides to keep your baby warm and safe.
A small tube that is put in your baby\'s nose or mouth and goes down into their stomach. it helps to feed your baby breast milk or formula.
A type of IV that is in your baby\'s hand, foot, leg, or scalp to give your baby fluids, nutrients, or medications.
A type of light that is used to help break down bilirubin in your baby\'s blood
A wire that is attached to your baby\'s foot or wrist to monitor the amount of oxygen in their blood.
A type of IV that is in your baby\'s umbilical cord to give your baby fluids, nutrients or medications.
A pediatrician with special training in the care of very sick and premature babies. The neonatologist is in charge of your baby’s care.
Pediatricians who are getting more training in the care of sick and premature babies. They work in the NICU and report to the neonatologist.
Residents are doctors who are learning about the care of sick children and premature babies. They are training to become pediatricians.
A nurse with advanced education and skills in the care of sick and premature babies, and their families.
The nurses who work in the NICU have training and experience in nursing care of sick babies and their families.
A Registered Nurse who is responsible for looking after the day-to-day activities in the unit.
The RT assists the nurses and doctors with the treatment and care of babies with breathing and lung problems.

Social Workers help individuals and families cope with problems they are facing, to improve their hospital stay. They can give you and your family practical and emotional support while your baby is in the hospital and when you are planning to go home.
The pharmacist works very closely with the doctors and nurses to provide safe medication therapy.

The occupational therapist assesses your baby’s development. An OT can plan activities for your baby to learn new skills. This can help overcome problems such as feeding difficulties, long-term hospital stays, and positioning care.
The dietitian works with the doctors and nurses to plan the best nutrition for your baby. The dietitian also helps mothers with breastfeeding support and advice about healthy eating.
The lactation consultant is a specially trained staff member who can support and help mothers with breastfeeding and pumping.

The business clerk greets and directs families and visitors in the NICU. The business clerk helps with telephone calls and mail, books tests and appointments for the babies. They help make the arrangements for babies’ admission, transfer and discharge.

The health care aide keeps equipment working, stocks the supplies in the unit, and takes specimens to the lab for testing. The HCA may also help the nurse during procedures, or when taking your baby for tests.
The environmental aide helps to keep the nursery clean. The EA is the person who washes all the incubators and baby warmers.

As this is a teaching hospital, you may meet student doctors, student nurses and other learners on the health care team. Each student works under the close supervision of a fully trained health professional. These learners may be involved in your baby’s care.

Holding your baby skin-to-skin is one of the best things you can do for your baby and it’s great for you as well! \n\n Kangaroo Care helps babies breathe, calms them, protects them from infection and helps their brain develop. It can also help you with breast milk production and bonding with your baby.
For babies that aren’t quite well enough for Kangaroo Care, you can still provide comfort by doing a hand-hug. This involves gently cupping your baby’s head and feet. Ask your nurse to show you how.
A hospital nursery that provides care to healthy newborn babies.

A hospital special care nursery that provides care to babies born after 32 weeks' gestation and weigh more than 1500 g. 

 Babies may need special care such as intravenous (IV) fluids, help with feeding, help with breathing or special medicine. 

 Babies in Level 2 may also be recovering from a more serious condition.

A hospital NICU that provides life support and specialized 24-hour care for babies that are very sick. This includes babies born at all gestational ages and weights, and babies born with complex and critical illnesses. 

 Babies who need level 3 care need to be watched very closely and need very special care. This includes help with breathing and feeding. 

 Babies in Level 3 may also need special medication, testing/imaging, or surgery.
